pr_title: Avoid `Connection reset by peer` error when server closes the connection

timeline.message: Account for the case when the server input shutdowns before output shutdown
Do not half-close INBOUND (reset) on graceful server closure
RequestResponseCloseHandlerTest: use IS event instead of implicit invocation of h.channelClosedInbound
Add tests to verify that read cancellation does not break graceful server shutdown

Revert "Use `pending == MAX_VALUE` instead of `CLOSING_SERVER_GRACEFULLY`"

This reverts commit da9727cc3bc3e2897e89eb27a2b254cdd8b6db30.
Fire UserEvent instead of registering a handler to discard inbound

Do not abort server write if connection is in closing state

Server may register a write after HttpRequestDecoder is already processed
the request with "Connection: close" header. As the result, server can not
respond if the write is aborted.

timeline.bodyText:
@NiteshKant upgrade to TLSv1.3 (client starts writing data earlier than server completes the handshake) helped to discover this issue, resulting in a lot of failed tests: https://ci.servicetalk.io/job/servicetalk-java11-prb/1521/
My fix isn't great: 5c5b41c. Open for suggestions.
timeline.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.message: ProxyTunnel: flush all written data before closing streams

Revert "Do not abort server write if connection is in closing state"

This reverts commit 5c5b41c3

timeline.author: NiteshKant

replies.bodyText: Not a strong requirement, but makes logs a bit nicer by removing random numbers at the end of these events.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText: I don't think we should depend on ordering between listener invocation and subscriber termination. Can you explain more what is the issue here and why was it not evident before?
timeline.author: NiteshKant

replies.bodyText:
If we invoke listeners before the write is complete, it will trigger protocolPayloadEndOutboundSuccess that initiates connection closure before the write is complete. As the result, the pipeline will see ChannelOutputShutdownEvent and trigger WSS#channelClosed changing the terminal signal from onComplete to onError.
CloseHandler does not know about the state of WSS to defer closure until the write is complete.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: Netty invokes listeners after it processes the completion of the promise. I think we should do the same and first complete the subscriber, then notify listeners.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText:
I am not convinced this is doing anything useful since we are following first writer-wins with events that can be concurrent and are sequenced through the event loop queue.
If this isn't really required for this change, i would prefer considering as a followup
timeline.author: NiteshKant
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -73,13 +78,21 @@
      */
     private int pending;
 
+    /**
+     * Original {@link CloseEvent} that initiated closing.
+     */
+    @Nullable
+    private CloseEvent event;

replies.bodyText:
We currently have a similar problem in DefaultNettyConnection. The first close event wins.
This is required to understand later how should we close the connection: gracefully or not. Without storing the original reason we can not make a correct decision at the time when we are ready to close.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: I created a diagram that tells when the state has to be updated. For this PR, it's ok to leave it as-is. In a follow-up PR, to improve understanding of the connection closure, I will add a logic that updates the event here shares it with DefaultNettyConnection.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText: Did you mean to use evt here instead of event as the callers of this method are reading event?
timeline.author: NiteshKant

timeline.bodyText: I am concerned about splitting the state b/w state and event. Can we set SERVER_CLOSING_GRACEFULLY upfront so that we do not have to rely on event here?
timeline.author: NiteshKant

replies.bodyText:
SERVER_CLOSING_GRACEFULLY used by logic that handles shutdown events and the requirement there is to set this flag only when we shutdown outbound gracefully. I will need another flag if I can not use evt.
Here we use the originated reason for closure to decide if we need to close gracefully or not.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: After investigating it more, I'm actually planning to do the opposite. The CLOSING state is not useful in many cases as it does not tell the reason for the closure. I plan to remove CLOSING and use event != null instead of has(state, CLOSING). In some cases, like this one, the event matters.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText: Can we move this to the receiver of the discard event?
timeline.author: NiteshKant

timeline.message:
Revert "Support EmbeddedChannel in RequestResponseCloseHandler"

This reverts commit f8c89080
Add tests for graceful closure when UDS is used
Simulate FIN from the client in ServerRespondsOnClosingTest
Test that server discards further requests while it is in graceful closure state
Ignore flushes without written objects in `OutboundWriteEventsInterceptor`

timeline.bodyText: do we have to expose this method? ByteToMessageDecoder should clean up the cumulation when it is removed from the pipeline, not clear why we need to explicitly call this method.
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText: It may have some data in the cumulation buffer. On handlerRemoved event it will fire those pending data through the pipeline. By releasing it manually, we can avoid seeing more data.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: @Scottmitch you were right, when we do replace, netty first adds a new handler after the current one and then removes the existing handler. Therefore, even if we had something in the accumulation buffer, it will be discarded by the new handler. So, we can avoid exposing releaseCumulation() 🎉
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText: reminder @normanmaurer: we should fix half closure in Netty so actions go through the pipeline instead of the channel bypassing handlers.
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText: There is also ChannelOutputShutdownEvent fired through the pipeline. Can you please clarify what event we need in addition to that?
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: Half closure is an example that bypasses the pipeline (due to organically added support over time). Some handlers would like to participate in state machine of channels (channel initialization/active/open/handshake/wrtiability/queuing/etc.), but in some cases the channel doesn't propagate the events through the pipeline. So for example in this case we have to reach into the pipeline and invoke a specific handler in order to cleanup "correctly". Ideally the events can flow through the pipeline so handlers can intercept/interpret these events as necessary.
replies.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText: I see. Agreed, some other event prior the output shutdown will be useful for SslHandler to intercept it and emit close_nofity.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText:
we lose the ability to apply back pressure at this point. which may lead to a surprising "attack" vector from the user perspective. Consider adding a comment and reference to s6.6 (client writes before it receives FIN, server responds with RST, client TCP stack doesn't deliver buffered data when RST received).
Did you explore alternative approaches (e.g. not read at all)? Even if we don't ask to read data for the native transports Netty will read/drain if a FIN/RST is received (via RDHUP), which means we will pickup on the FIN/RST as soon as it is delivered (assuming it is delivered). However if the client has more data to send than can be queued in its sendbuf (or that can fit in the server recvbuf) then the server won't see the FIN_ACK from the client until reading/draining data. However maybe this isn't a problem as if the client continues to read (which is expected) it will eventually see the server's close and should stop trying to write.
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText:
Hmm, interesting idea. I thought that we have to keep reading data from the channel to receive FIN in all cases, even if recvbuf is not full. What will happen on the pipeline if we do not request read() anymore but then native transport observes FIN? IIUC, AbstractEpollChannel will never fire ChannelInputShutdownReadComplete if we do not request to read, but we depend on this event in DefaultNettyConnection. Also, will the behavior change with Java NIO transport?
The shutdownInput() also discards all new arriving data without applying backpressure. The only difference is that we will never see FIN if we invoke shutdownInput() manually, that's why I have to implement /dev/null handler. And it looks like a safer option, without relying on native transport behavior (RDHUP).
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: Discussed offline: OS behaves in a similar way after shutdownInput(). Will keep the existing approach for now.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText: can you remove the "keep reading" point here in case we do something different? Consider describing the problem with shutdownInput() (e.g. client send data, server rst, client sees rst and discards read queue) and that the protocol can handle the closure more gracefully.
timeline.author: Scottmitch

timeline.bodyText: USER_CLOSING -> can you plz rename this (and userClosingmethod) to include graceful? not introduced by this PR but it is confusing when the concepts are mixed together.
timeline.author: Scottmitch

timeline.bodyText:
consider renaming to avoid "discard" because we are assuming what action will be taken as a result of this event but don't control what is being done.
DISCARDING_SERVER_INPUT -> IN_SHUTDOWN
DiscardFurtherInboundEvent -> GracefulInputShutdownEvent
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText:
IN_SHUTDOWN may be a bit misleading, because it actually is not shutdown. IN_CLOSED is set when the input is shutdown.
The discard of input happens not only for graceful closure but also for other events, like protocol closing inbound/outbound, when we are not expecting more requests. Named it DiscardFurtherInboundEvent because it's kind of a request to discard without saying how exactly it should be discarded.
Happy to rename, just looking for better alternatives...
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.bodyText: not introduced by this PR but the control flow here is somewhat confusing. This method is called before the trailers are actually written, and eventually goes to WriteStreamSubscriber#channelOutboundClosed which calls sourceTerminated, which will complete the promise if activeWrites==0 but since we haven't written yet I assume that is never possible?
timeline.author: Scottmitch

replies.bodyText:
Agreed, the flow here is confusing. It was originally introduced in #919 and later improved (there was a bug) in #1155, according to the original logic from #919.
IIUC this was done specifically for h2. The event is emitted before write, because netty closes the stream in write listener. But not sure if it need to be done in the same way for h1. I had an idea of how to simplify it by merging protocolPayloadEndOutbound and protocolPayloadEndOutboundSuccess together. Implementations of CloseHandler for h1 and h2 are anyway different. But did not have time to experiment. Decided to stop introducing more concurrent PRs for the same part of the codebase.
replies.author: idelpivnitskiy

timeline.message: Test that PROTOCOL_CLOSING_OUTBOUND closes the connection even if it's already in USER_CLOSING state and more pipelined requests pending
Do not use offloading in ServerRespondsOnClosingTest
